properties.name: Dayrin — ܕܝܪܝܢ
properties.desc: One of the islands in Beth Qaṭraye Attestation of name ܕܝܪܝܢ in the Synodicon Orientale. Attestation of names دارين and الدارين in the Kitāb al-masālik wa-l-mamālik of Abuʾl-Qāsim Ibn Khurradādhbih. Attestation of name دارين in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad b. Muḥammad al-Hamadhānī Ibn al-Faqīh.

properties.name: Wadi Dara - ܢܗܪܐ ܕܒܝܬ ܘܫܝ
properties.desc: "Joh. Eph., EH 6.26, records that the Persian army retreated to a small river after their defeat at Tella in June 582. Michael Whitby has identified this river as the Wadi Dara (also called Wadi Jarrah), a tributary of the Khabur close to Dara."

properties.name: Taprobane
properties.desc: The island of Sri Lanka off the coast of India Attestation of name طبروباني in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Greece — ܗܠܐܕܐ
properties.desc: "The region located at the southern end of the Balkan Peninsula."

properties.name: Thessalonica - ܬܣܠܘܢܝܩܐ
properties.desc: "One of the most important Roman cities on the Balkan peninsula, Thessalonica was provincial capital of Macedonia prima and the administrative center of the whole Illyrian prefecture. Prior to the rise of Constantinople, it was even imperial capital during parts of the 4th century."

properties.name: Thrace — ܬܪܩܝܐ
properties.desc: "A region in south-eastern Europe, Thrace was in Late Antiquity the name of both a diocese and a province."

properties.name: Sophanene - ܒܝܬ ܨܘ̈ܦܢܝܐ
properties.desc: "Sophanene was the name of a region in the southern part of Armenia, not to be confused with the neighbouring Sophene."

properties.name: Adriatic Sea
properties.desc: The sea between Italy and Greece Attestation of name أذريس in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Britain
properties.desc: An island northwest of Europe Attestation of name برطينية in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Mazun — ܡܙܘܢ
properties.desc: A diocese of the southeastern Arabian Peninsula on the shores of the Persian Gulf Attestation of name ܡܙܘܢ in the Synodicon Orientale. Attestation of name ܡܙܘܢ in the Synodicon Orientale. Attestation of name ܡܙܘܢ in the Synodicon Orientale.

properties.name: Tralles — ܛܪܠܝܘ
properties.desc: "An important city in Late Antiquity in the region of Caria in western Asia minor."

properties.name: Thebais — ܬܐܒܝܣ
properties.desc: "One of the provinces into which Roman Egypt was subdivided, the Thebais formed the southern part of Egypt."

properties.name: Sergius and Bacchus, Church of - ܒܝܬ ܩܕܝܫܐ ܡܪܝ ܣܪܓܝܣ
properties.desc: "While there is some debate as to whether Justinian started the construction of this church before or after his accession to the imperial throne in 527, it was certainly completed by the mid-530s. It was located to the south-west of the Great Palace, directly adjacent to the Hormisdas Palace. There also was a monastery which housed many miaphysite monks and clerics during the 530s and 540s."

properties.name: Red Sea
properties.desc: "The sea between Egypt/Nubia and Arabia is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 4.51 and 53."

properties.name: Gulf of Aden
properties.desc: The bay which separates the Arabian Peninsula from the Horn of Africa Attestation of name الخليج البربري in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Ḥaṭṭa — ܚܛܐ
properties.desc: A diocese based in northeastern Arabia near al-Qaṭīf Attestation of name ܚܛܐ in the Synodicon Orientale.

properties.name: ʿAyn Shams
properties.desc: A city in Egypt Attestation of name عين شمس in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Sirmium — ܣܪܡܝܘܢ
properties.desc: "An important imperial residence close to the Danube in Pannonia in the 4th century, Sirmium fell to Gothic and Gepid groups in the 5th century. The Romans reconquered it in the late 560s, but it definitely fell to the Avars in the early 580s, as recorded in Joh. Eph., EH 6.32 and 33."

properties.name: Sirmin - ܣܪܡܝܢ
properties.desc: "A village 60km southeast of Antioch. John III Scholasticus, patriarch of Constantinople 565-577, hailed from this place."

properties.name: Mashmahig — ܡܫܡܗܝܓ
properties.desc: An episcopal see on an island in Beth Qaṭraye Attestation of name ܡܫܡܗܝܓ in the Synodicon Orientale. Attestation of name ܡܝܫܡܗܓ in the Synodicon Orientale.

properties.name: Mareotis - ܡܪܝܘܛܐ
properties.desc: "A district and town to the south-west of Alexandria, famous for its freshwater lake."

properties.name: Aulai - ܐܘܠܣ
properties.desc: "A town in Cilicia. Joh. Eph., EH 5.4, mentions that the tritheist bishop Conon lived in a female monastery there in the mid-570s."

properties.name: Chlomaron - ܟܠܝܡܪ
properties.desc: "Chlomaron was a Persian fortress in Armenia close to the border with the Roman Empire and adjacent to the fortress of Aphum. Joh. Eph., EH 6.34, records that Maurice failed to take this fortress during his campaign in 578."

properties.name: Euchaita — ܐܘܟܐܛܐ
properties.desc: A settlment in northern Anatolia.

properties.name: al-Dāmaghān
properties.desc: A large town between al-Ray and Naysābūr Attestation of name الدامغان in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Casium — ܩܣܝܢ
properties.desc: "A monastery located on the seacoast, at the border between Egypt and Syria. Joh. Eph., EH 4.33, states that Jacob Burd'oyo and several of his companions died there in summer 578 when traveling to Egypt."

properties.name: ܿBeth Urtaye — ܒܝܬ ܐܘܪ̈ܛܝܐ
properties.desc: "A region in southern Armenia, often called Beth Urtaye in Syriac. The miaphysite bishop George, mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 4.10, hailed from this place."

properties.name: Qūmis
properties.desc: A region between al-Ray and Naysābūr, around al-Dāmaghān Attestation of name قومس in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Masqaṭ
properties.desc: A city in ʿUmān Attestation of name مسقط in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: al-Kurr
properties.desc: The river that runs beside Tbilisi and into the Caspian Sea Attestation of name الكر in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Dorylaion — ܕܐܘܪܠܝܘܢ
properties.desc: A settlement in norther Phrygia.

properties.name: Arabissus - ܐܪܒܝܣܘܣ
properties.desc: "A city in Cappadocia, it was the hometown of emperor Maurice (582-602), who embellished it with the construction of representative builidings, as is stated in Joh. Eph., EH 5.22 and 23."

properties.name: Persarmenia - ܐܪܡܢܝܐ ܪܒܬܐ ܕܦܪܣܝܐ
properties.desc: "Originally an independent kingdom situated between the Roman and Sasanian Empires, Armenia was divided between the two powers in the late 4th century. Almost four-fifths came under Sasanian dominion, and this part, with Dvin as its capital, is known as Persarmenia or Sasanian Armenia. Joh. Eph., EH 2.18-22, deals with the Sasanian persecution of the Armenian Christians in the early 570s."

properties.name: Pythia - ܦܬܝܐ
properties.desc: "Joh. Eph., EH 2.46, mentions that the Kathara monastery given to a group of expelled miaphysite monks from Cappadocia was close to the therms of Pythia in Bithynia. This was a very popular spa resort for people from Constantinople, including the imperial court, throughout the Byzantine period."

properties.name: Batman (river) - ܟܠܬ
properties.desc: "The Batman, in antiquity known as Kalat in Syriac and Nymphaios in Greek, is a tributary of the Tigris. It is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 6.36."

properties.name: Aksum
properties.desc: "A kingdom in northern Ethiopia that converted to Christianity in the early 4th century. Joh. Eph., EH 4.53, holds that the inhabitants of Aksum adhered to the doctrines of Julian of Halicarnassus in the later sixth century."

properties.name: Isauria — ܐܝܣܘܪܝܐ
properties.desc: "A mountainous region of southern Anatolia known for its warlike and often rebellious population."

properties.name: Naysābūr
properties.desc: A city of Khurasan Attestation of name نيسابور in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: al-Dīnawar
properties.desc: A city between Qarmāsīn and Hamadān Attestation of name الدينور in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Qazwīn
properties.desc: A city in northwestern Iran Attestation of name قزوين in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Warthān
properties.desc: A city on the river al-Rass Attestation of name ورثان in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī. Attestation of name ورثان in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Abarne — ܐܒܪ̈ܢܐ
properties.desc: A settlement in northern Mesopotamia.

properties.name: Akbas - ܐܩܒܐ
properties.desc: "Akbas was a Persian fortress on the river Batman close to Martyropolis in southern Armenia. Joh. Eph., EH 6.36, describes its capture and destruction by the Romans in 583."

properties.name: Bithynia - ܒܝܬܘܢܝܐ
properties.desc: "A region and Roman province in north-western Asia Minor."

properties.name: Citharizon - ܩܝܬܪܝܙ
properties.desc: "A fortress in the Roman part of Armenia close to Theodosiopolis and Persarmenia. Joh. Eph., EH 6.14, mentions this place."

properties.name: Philae - ܦܝܠܘܢ
properties.desc: "Located on an island in the First Nile Cataract, Philae was a major cultic centre for the goddess Isis. Traces have been unearthed that pagan rituals took place there until the mid-5th century, yet already since the early 4th century, Philae was also an episcopal see."

properties.name: Samaria - ܫܡܪܝܢ
properties.desc: "Situated to the north of Jerusalem, Samaria formed the core of the ancient kingdom of Israel. Its inhabitants, the Samaritans, preserved their religious customs in Late Antiquity and repeatedly revolted against the Roman Empire in the sixth century. Joh. Eph., EH 2.29, polemically establishes a connection between Samaritans and persecutors of Christians."

properties.name: Africa — ܐܦܪܝܩܐ
properties.desc: "Roman Africa was centred around its capital Carthage and one of the richest and most fertile regions of the empire."

properties.name: Daphne - ܕܦܢܐ
properties.desc: "Daphne was an opulent western suburb of Antioch. There were large residential areas and a number of important churches."

properties.name: Aphum - ܦܘܡ
properties.desc: "Aphum was a fortification in the Roman-Persian border area in southern Armenia to the east of Martyropolis and the river Batman. Joh. Eph., EH 6.34, records that Maurice conquered it from the Persians in 578."

properties.name: Jalūlāʾ
properties.desc: A town northeast of Baghdad Attestation of name جلولاء in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: ʿAdan
properties.desc: A city in southern Yemen Attestation of name عدن in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Mihrān
properties.desc: The Indus River in what is today Pakistan Attestation of name مهران in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Cappadocia — ܩܦܘܕܩܝܐ
properties.desc: "A region of central Anatolia which was subdivided in several provinces in Late Antiquity."

properties.name: Danube - ܕܘܢܒܝܣ ܢܗܪܐ
properties.desc: "A river in central and south-eastern Europe, formerly known as the Istros. Joh. Eph., EH 6.24 and 31, mentions this river."

properties.name: The Patriarchal Palace of Constantinople - ܒܝܬ ܐܦܝܣܩܦܝܘܢ
properties.desc: "The residence of the patriarchs of Constantinople was adjacent to Hagia Sophia and provided direct access to the south-western corner of the church. Joh. Eph., EH 1.18-29, mentions it as the place where he and other miaphysite bishops were imprisoned and forced to accept an edict of union with the Chalcedonians."

properties.name: Mar Menas — ܡܪܝ ܡܐܢܐ
properties.desc: "A monastery and pilgrimage centre about 60 km south-west of Alexandria in the Mareotis region. During the 5th and 6th centuries, the monastery developed into one of the largest monastery complexes in Egypt."

properties.name: Hagia Sophia (Great Church) - ܥܕܬܐ ܪܒܬܐ
properties.desc: "The monumental main church of Constantinople was destroyed during the Nika riots in 532, then rebuilt by Justinian on an even greater scale. Known as the Great Church, it played a major role in imperial ceremonies throughout the Byzantine period."

properties.name: Nea Theotokos monastery - ܕܝܪܐ ܚܕܬܐ
properties.desc: "The monumental complex of the Nea Church in Jerusalem, dedicated to the Mother of God, included a monastery and was founded by Justinian in 543. Joh. Eph., EH 1.32, mentions that Photius, stepson of Belisarius, was abbot of the monastery belonging to the church."

properties.name: Alodia
properties.desc: "Alodia was a Nubian kingdom located to the south of Nobadia and Makouria. Joh.Eph., EH 4.48-53, narrates the missionary work of the miaphysite bishop Longinus there in the late 570s. In 4.53 and 55, John adds that Alodia was also known under the name Ethiopia (ܐܬܝܘܦܝܐ)."

properties.name: al-Rass
properties.desc: A river flowing from near Erzerum in modern Turkey through Armenia and Adharbayjān Attestation of name الرس in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Kābul
properties.desc: A city between India and Sijistān Attestation of name كابل in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Qumm
properties.desc: A city east of Hamadān and north of Ispahan Attestation of name قم in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Anchialus - ܐܢܟܝܠܘܣ
properties.desc: "Anchialus, modern Pomorie in Bulgaria, was a city in Thrace on the west coast of the Black Sea."

properties.name: Mary of Blachernai (church) - ܒܝܬ ܡܪܬܝ ܡܪܝܐ ܕܒܠܩܪܢܐ
properties.desc: "A church in north-western Constantinople. Joh. Eph., EH 2.16, mentions a priest named Comitas who was part of the clergy of this church."

properties.name: Seleucia-Ctesiphon — ܣܠܝܩ ܘܩܛܝܣܦܘܢ
properties.desc: "Located on the Tigris, south of modern Baghdad. 483. Seleucia-Ctesiphon ܬܰܪܬܝܢ ܡܕܝ̈ܢܳܢ ܕܒܰܚܕ̈ܕܐ ܣܒܝܣ̈ܢ ܘܡܶܬܩܰܪ̈ܝܳܢ ܡܕܝ̈ܢܳܬܐ ܐܶܡܐ ܕܰܡܕܝ̈ܢܬܳܐ ܕܦܳܪ̈ܣܳܝܐ ܣܰܐܣܰܐܢܳܝ̈ܐ ܠܬܰܝܡܢܳܗ̇ ܕܒܓܕܕ ܡܰܪܕܶܐ ܫܶܬ ܫܳܥܝ̈ܢ ܘܰܚܪܶܒ̈ܝ ܒܫܘܪܳܝ ܫܘܠܛܳܢܐ ܕܥܰܪ̈ܒܝܐ ܘܰܒܓܰܢܒܗܝܢ ܝܰܘܡܳܢ ܩܪܝܬܳܐ ܕܣܰܠܡܰܐܢ ܒܰܐܟ. مدينتان متصلتان سميتا بالمدائن عاصمة الفرس الساسانيين، جنوبي بغداد مسيرة ست ساعات، خربتا في صدر الفتح العربي وبجانبهما اليوم قرية سلمان باك. two connected cities. They were the capital of the Sassanids, situated about six hours journey south of Baghdad. Both these cities were destroyed at the beginning of the Arab conquest. Near their site is the present village of Salman Pak."

properties.name: Heraclea (Perinthus) - ܗܪܩܠܝܐ
properties.desc: "Metropolis of the Late Roman province Europa in Thrace, its significance dwindled in Late Antiquity because of the rise of Constantinople which was located only 90km to the east. Joh. Eph., EH 1.9, mentions it as a place of exile for miaphysites."

properties.name: Semkhart - ܫܡܟܪܬ
properties.desc: "According to Joh. Eph., EH 6.35, Maurice, as commander of the Roman forces in the east, erected a fortress called Semkhart next to a mountain with the same name in the Armenian region of Sophanene in the early 580s. The place is called Samocharta in the Greek sources."

properties.name: Daphnudium - ܕܦܢܘܕܝܢ
properties.desc: "This settlement, mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 3.8, as the place of origin of Ino Anastasia, is tentatively identified with the island of Daphnusia off the Black Sea coast of Bithynia."

properties.name: Hormisda — ܗܘܪܡܙܕܐ
properties.desc: "An imperial palace in Constantinople, built in the 5th century directly to the south-west of the Great Palace."

properties.name: Nahāwand
properties.desc: A city south of Hamadān Attestation of name نهاوند in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Sardis - ܣܪܕܐ
properties.desc: "The capital of Lydia, Sardis was one of the most important cities in Asia Minor throughout Antiquity and into the Byzantine period."

properties.name: Hebdomon - ܐܒܕܡܘܢ
properties.desc: "The Hebdomon was a coastal suburb located seven miles to the west of Constantinople. In Late Antiquity, it possessed an important imperial residence and large parade grounds for the army, hence it was also referred to in Greek as πρόκενσον (prokenson). Emperors were, upon their accession, acclaimed by the army on the parade ground of the Hebdomon in the later fourth and fifth centuries."

properties.name: Mihrijānqadhaq
properties.desc: A region around al-Ṣaymara in western Iran Attestation of name مهرجانقذق in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Asia — ܐܣܝܐ
properties.desc: "A civil diocese in the western part of Anatolia, also the name of a Roman province."

properties.name: Ganges
properties.desc: A river in northern and northeastern India Attestation of name كنك in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Great Palace of Constantinople - ܦܠܛܝܢ
properties.desc: "The Great Palace was the residential complex of the East Roman emperors throughout Late Antiquity. Located at the south-eastern end of Constantinople, it consisted of several palaces and witnessed continuous building activity."

properties.name: Makouria
properties.desc: "A kingdom located in Nubia, situated between the kingdoms of Nobadia and Alodia. Joh. Eph., EH 4.51 and 53, speaks of the people of Makouria."

properties.name: Bassos, Monastery of Mar - ܕܝܪܐ ܕܡܪܝ ܒܣ
properties.desc: "This monastery was located in north-western Syria, about 30 km from Chalcis. The miaphysite bishop John of Chalcis probably resided there, as is recorded in Joh. Eph., EH 4.10."

properties.name: al-Nahrawān
properties.desc: A river in eastern Iraq Attestation of name النهروان in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Aphrodisias — ܐܦܪܘܕܝܣܝܕܐ
properties.desc: "The metropolis of the province of Caria in south-western Anatolia."

properties.name: al-Ray
properties.desc: A city in northern Iran Attestation of name الري in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: al-Daylam
properties.desc: A region in northern Iran Attestation of name الديلم in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī. Attestation of name الديلم in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Tell Beshme - ܬܠܒܫܡܐ
properties.desc: "A town in Roman Mesopotamia. Its surroundings were pillaged by the Persians under Adarmahan in the 570s, as recorded in Joh. Eph., EH 6.13."

properties.name: Dvin - ܕܐܘܝܢ
properties.desc: "Founded in the 4th century, Dvin was the capital of Armenia. After the loss of the Armenian independence and the partition of the region between Rome and the Sasanian Empire, Dvin became the residence of the Sasanian governor of Persarmenia. Joh. Eph., EH 2.18-22, deals with the Sasanian persecution of the Armenian Christians that took place there in the early 570s."

properties.name: Libya — ܠܘܒܐ
properties.desc: "The region of northern Africa to the east of Egypt, including the Cyrenaica."

properties.name: Plateia - ܦܠܛܝܐ
properties.desc: "The modern Yassiada, in Greek called Plate or Plateia. This is one of the Princes' Islands close to Constantinople where recalcitrant clerics were frequently sent into exile in Late Antiquity and the Byzantine period. Joh. Eph., EH 1.16, notes that the miaphysite bishop Stephen of Cyprus was maltreated there."

properties.name: Hippodrome of Constantinople - ܐܦܝܩܘܣ
properties.desc: "The great hippodrome of Constantinople was situated directly adjacent to the imperial palace. This was one of the few places where the people could interact with the emperor via acclamations."

properties.name: Jurjān
properties.desc: A city between Tabaristan and Khurasan Attestation of name جرجان in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Kirmān
properties.desc: A city in southeastern Iran Attestation of name كرمان in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Antioch in Caria — ܐܢܛܝܘܟ ܕܩܪܝܐܐ
properties.desc: "A city in Caria in south-western Anatolia, also known as Antioch on the Maeander. John of Ephesus, EH 1.14 records that Paul of Aphrodisias was made bishop there after embracing the council of Chalcedon."

properties.name: Māsabadhān
properties.desc: A region near Mihrijānqadhaq Attestation of name ماسبذان in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī.

properties.name: Acoemetae, Monastery of the - ܕܝܪܐ ܕܐܩܝܡܛܘܢ
properties.desc: "Famous for their perpetual worship, the movement of the Acoemetae (sleepless monks), founded at the start of the 5th century, eventually settled in a monastery on the Asian side of the Bosphorus. The monks were staunchly dyophysite, to such an extent that they were suspected of harbouring Nestorian sympathies and condemned in the early 530s. Nevertheless, their monastery remained important and served as a place of imprisonment for miaphysite clerics, as is mentioned in Joh. Eph., EH 1.17."

properties.name: Indian Ocean
properties.desc: The ocean bordering East Africa, South Asia, and Australia Attestation of name بحر الهند وفارس والصين in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Ḥaṭṭa
properties.desc: A town in northeastern Arabia near al-Qaṭīf Attestation of name الخط in the Kitāb al-masālik wa-l-mamālik of Abuʾl-Qāsim Ibn Khurradādhbih. Attestation of name الخط in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad b. Muḥammad al-Hamadhānī Ibn al-Faqīh.

properties.name: Leiden
properties.desc: A city in the Netherlands

properties.name: Hagar — ܗܓܪ
properties.desc: A diocese in northeastern Arabia Attestation of name ܗܓܪ in the Synodicon Orientale.

properties.name: Hagar
properties.desc: A town in northeastern Arabia Attestation of name هجر in the Kitāb al-masālik wa-l-mamālik of Abuʾl-Qāsim Ibn Khurradādhbih. Attestation of name هجر in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad b. Muḥammad al-Hamadhānī Ibn al-Faqīh.

properties.name: Hagar and Pīṭ Ardashīr — ܗܓܪ ܘܦܝܛܐܪܕܫܝܪ
properties.desc: A diocese in northeastern Arabia near al-Qaṭīf Attestation of name ܗܓܪ ܘܦܝܛܐܪܕܫܝܪ in the Synodicon Orientale.

properties.name: al-Qaṭīf
properties.desc: One of the largest cities in the region of al-Baḥrayn Attestation of name القطيف in the Kitāb al-masālik wa-l-mamālik of Abuʾl-Qāsim Ibn Khurradādhbih. Attestation of name القطيف in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad b. Muḥammad al-Hamadhānī Ibn al-Faqīh.

properties.name: Mecca
properties.desc: A city in Arabia, regarded by Muslims as the holiest city Attestation of name مكة in the Kitāb al-buldān of Aḥmad ibn Abī Yaʿqūb al-Yaʿqūbī. Attestation of name مكّة in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: Zeuxippus, Baths of - ܙܘܩܣܦܘܣ
properties.desc: "Situated very close to the Great Palace, Hagia Sophia and the hippodrome, the baths of Zeuxippus were the most famous public baths of Constantinople. Throughout Late Antiquity, emperors brought statues and other renowned works of art to Constantinople, many of which were put on display in the baths of Zeuxippus. The baths were burned down in 532 during the Nika riots and rebuilt by Justinian I. Joh. Eph., EH 3.24, refers to the eastern part of the city near the seashore by the name Zeuxippus, likely because of the prominence of the baths."

properties.name: Don River
properties.desc: A river that flows into the Black Sea from the north Attestation of name طانيس in the Kitāb al-aʿlāq al-nafīsa of Aḥmad ibn ʿUmar Ibn Rustah.

properties.name: al-ʿUqayr
properties.desc: A coastal village near Hagar in al-Baḥrayn Attestation of name العقير in the Kitāb al-masālik wa-l-mamālik of Abuʾl-Qāsim Ibn Khurradādhbih.

properties.name: Corinth — ܩܘܪܝܢܬܘܣ
properties.desc: "Located at the entrance to the Peloponnese, Corinth was the metropolis of the Roman province of Achaea."
